commands.description: push local or remote into Heroku database
commands.help:
[1mUsage:[22m heroku pg:push SOURCE TARGET [34m[flags][39m

[1mpush local or remote into Heroku database[22m

[34mFlags:[39m
 -a, --app APP                            [2mapp to run command against[22m
 -r, --remote REMOTE                      [2mgit remote of app to use[22m
 --exclude-table-data EXCLUDE-TABLE-DATA  [2mtables for which data should be excluded (use ';' to split multiple names)[22m

Push from SOURCE into TARGET. TARGET must be empty.

To empty a Heroku database for push run `heroku pg:reset`

SOURCE must be either the name of a database existing on your localhost or the
fully qualified URL of a remote database.

Examples:

    # push mylocaldb into a Heroku DB named postgresql-swimmingly-100
    $ heroku pg:push mylocaldb postgresql-swimmingly-100

    # push remote DB at postgres://myhost/mydb into a Heroku DB named postgresql-swimmingly-100
    $ heroku pg:push postgres://myhost/mydb postgresql-swimmingly-100
helpLine: [2mpush local or remote into Heroku database[22m

commands.description: pull Heroku database into local or remote database
commands.help:
[1mUsage:[22m heroku pg:pull SOURCE TARGET [34m[flags][39m

[1mpull Heroku database into local or remote database[22m

[34mFlags:[39m
 -a, --app APP                            [2mapp to run command against[22m
 -r, --remote REMOTE                      [2mgit remote of app to use[22m
 --exclude-table-data EXCLUDE-TABLE-DATA  [2mtables for which data should be excluded (use ';' to split multiple names)[22m

Pull from SOURCE into TARGET.

TARGET must be one of:
  * a database name (i.e. on a local PostgreSQL server)  => TARGET must not exist and will be created
  * a fully qualified URL to a local PostgreSQL server   => TARGET must not exist and will be created
  * a fully qualified URL to a remote PostgreSQL server  => TARGET must exist and be empty

To delete a local database run `dropdb TARGET`
To create an empty remote database, run `createdb` with connection command-line options (run `createdb --help` for details).

Examples:

    # pull Heroku DB named postgresql-swimmingly-100 into local DB mylocaldb that must not exist
    $ heroku pg:pull postgresql-swimmingly-100 mylocaldb --app sushi

    # pull Heroku DB named postgresql-swimmingly-100 into empty remote DB at postgres://myhost/mydb
    $ heroku pg:pull postgresql-swimmingly-100 postgres://myhost/mydb --app sushi
helpLine: [2mpull Heroku database into local or remote database[22m

commands.description: Controls whether a log message is produced when a session waits longer than the deadlock_timeout to acquire a lock. deadlock_timeout is set to 1 second
commands.help:
[1mUsage:[22m heroku pg:settings:log-lock-waits [VALUE] [DATABASE] [34m[flags][39m

[1mControls whether a log message is produced when a session waits longer than the deadlock_timeout to acquire a lock. deadlock_timeout is set to 1 second[22m

[34mFlags:[39m
 -a, --app APP        [2mapp to run command against[22m
 -r, --remote REMOTE  [2mgit remote of app to use[22m

Delays due to lock contention occur when multiple transactions are trying to access the same resource at the same time.
Applications and their query patterns should try to avoid changes to many different tables within the same transaction.
helpLine: [2mControls whether a log message is produced when a session waits longer than the deadlock_timeout to acquire a lock. deadlock_timeout is set to 1 second[22m

commands.description:
The duration of each completed statement will be logged if the statement completes after the time specified by VALUE.
VALUE needs to specified as a whole number, in milliseconds.
commands.help:
[1mUsage:[22m heroku pg:settings:log-min-duration-statement [VALUE] [DATABASE] [34m[flags][39m

[1mThe duration of each completed statement will be logged if the statement completes after the time specified by VALUE.[22m
[1mVALUE needs to specified as a whole number, in milliseconds.[22m

[34mFlags:[39m
 -a, --app APP        [2mapp to run command against[22m
 -r, --remote REMOTE  [2mgit remote of app to use[22m

Setting log_min_duration_statement to zero prints all statement durations and -1 will disable logging statement durations.
helpLine:
[2mThe duration of each completed statement will be logged if the statement completes after the time specified by VALUE.[22m
[2mVALUE needs to specified as a whole number, in milliseconds.[22m

commands.description: log_statement controls which SQL statements are logged.
commands.help:
[1mUsage:[22m heroku pg:settings:log-statement [VALUE] [DATABASE] [34m[flags][39m

[1mlog_statement controls which SQL statements are logged.[22m

[34mFlags:[39m
 -a, --app APP        [2mapp to run command against[22m
 -r, --remote REMOTE  [2mgit remote of app to use[22m

Valid values for VALUE:
none - No statements are logged
ddl  - All data definition statements, such as CREATE, ALTER and DROP will be logged
mod  - Includes all statements from ddl as well as data-modifying statements such as INSERT, UPDATE, DELETE, TRUNCATE, COPY
all  - All statements are logged
helpLine: [2mlog_statement controls which SQL statements are logged.[22m
